marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Letter to the territorial legislature from Claiborne stating that he had signed two bills: establishing the formation of Adams county, and creating the attorney-general post for the territory. Remainder of collection is photostat copy.
Collection was originally a part of the Don Preston Peters collection.
Business letters and a subpoena pertaining to Christopher Henderson Clark.

Two letters to William Churchill from a brother in the Mississippi Territory, commenting on farming conditions, the purchase of cattle, and the Creek War of 1813-1814 in Alabama; and two letters from a son who was a soldier in the Mexican War and later moved to Boston, Mass.

Collection consists of three letters to Dr. Theophilus Clark and Emily Clark from Caleb Smith Ives, an Episcopal clergyman, giving his impression of Alabama and describing his work there. Ives writes from Demopolis and Mobile and discusses cotton, plantation systems, immigration (including to Texas), local slang, churches, and economic conditions.

Miscellaneous business and personal correspondence from the Henry Clark (or Clarke) family, including a description by John D. Clark of an 1842 trip to the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys, particularly referencing Arkansas, and a pre-war letter from Jackson, Miss., which provides informationi on the family's living conditions in Mississippi. An undated letter written from Beaufort, N.C., during the Reconstruction period predicts gloomy prospects for the Southern economy, and accuses freedmen of being lazy and untrustworthy.
Cataloged from card file. Originally part of the Don Preston Peters Collection.

Collection contains personal correspondence, with letters largely addressed to Clarke from his brother (John H. Clarke), his son (Pleasant Henry Clarke), his wife (Martha M. Clarke), and other contacts concerning such subjects as national politics and elections (including the 1856 and 1868 presidential elections), medicine, and internal improvements in Virginia.
Farmer, son of Col. Leonard Claiborne (1791-1858) of "Mont Blanc," both residents of Pittsylvania county, Va. Married Jane A. Stone.

Account book, 1852-1856 (16 p.), containing scattered personal and agricultural accounts and memoranda including a record of crops planted in 1853, several payments to African Americans, transactions with neighbors and with Mrs. P.H. Stone, and a few remedies for burns, and for the treatment of hogs and horses. Other papers are a receipt for cooking oysters, a receipt for Mrs. Claiborne's daguerreotype and William Ayres' request for radish seeds.

Correspondence from various Clark family members concerning property; finances; desertion; commodity prices in North Carolina during the Civil War and the operation of the salt works at Wilmington; experiences in Alatoona, Georgia, during and after the Civil War; an 1867 contract with a former slave; and family affairs, including a love letter from Lucetta Wilson.
Farmer, of Locust Dale (Madison Co.), Va.

Letters and papers concerned with farm business, particularly with the sale of Clarke's farm products such as wheat, flour, tobacco, butter, and lard at Richmond markets. Clarke worked with the firm of Hill and Norfleet to sell his produce. Civil War-era letters reference the scarcity of salt and refence Clarke's business with the Quartermaster Department of the Confederate States of America.
Letter concerning the burning of a dwelling belonging to Mr. Jackson, located near the Claiborne's residence.

This collection is comprised of letters addressed by Jacob, Edward J., and Solomon Saylor to their sister, Sarah, while they served in the Union Army. Also included is a biographical sketch of Jacob completed by his granddaughter, Annabelle Saylor. Edward and Solomon Saylor enlisted in the 36th regiment of the Ohio Volunteer Militia in 1861. Jacob attempted to enlist with his brothers, but an Uncle retreived him from the regiment--he was only fifteen years old. Despite his age, later that year Jacob successfully enlisted in the 53rd Ohio Infantry. All the brothers' letters contain descriptions of camp life, military engagements, reported losses in both armies for battles, hardships, and their desire for furloughs. Jacob's correspondence suggests that he did much more hard marching and fighting than his brothers; however, Edward's letters mention that Solomon was wounded and probably taken prisoner twice. Jacob also writes about the formation of the Tennessee Colored Zouave Regiment, which African Americans were eager to volunteer to join. Jacob eventually served in Sherman's Army, and fought in Tennessee, Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia; Edward and Solomon fought mainly in Virginia and Tennessee.
Irish immigrant; resident of Elizabeth (Union Co.), N.J.
Civil War letters from William's brother Henry P. Clare, a soldier in the 9th Regiment, New York Infantry, describing camp life and the battle of Gettysburg.
U.S. Naval officer onboard the ironclad steamer, Sangamon. Clark attained the rank of third assistant engineer in 1863 and became second assistant engineer in 1866.

Collection consists of four letters from Clark to Charlotte, a friend, from Washington and South Carolina. In them he noted a trip to Beaufort, S.C.; damage and repairs to the Sangamon; the sinking of the U.S.S. Housatonic; gun practice in Charleston harbour; and picket duty near Ft. Sumter.
Resident from Scotland Neck, Halifax Co., N.C.

Two letters from C.M. Clark and his wife to their nephews, William and Tom. The Clarks express concern over not hearing from William, who was imprisoned on Johnson's Island in Sandusky, Ohio. Clark asks for news and whether N.C. soldiers there needed funds. He also mentions that Gov. Vance was hoping to send clothing to troops held there.

Collection consists of a letter from Clarke's son, William R. Clarke, a sergeant in the Union Army, written on May 15 while he was stationed in Keokuk, Iowa. Clarke mentions Jefferson Davis, his good wages, and his future plans. The lettersheets include three woodcuts depicting the Battle of Pittsburg Landing, the Bombardment of Ft. Henry, and the Bombardment of Island No. 10.
Rev. Dr. John Wesley Churchill (1839-1900) was professor of Religion in the Andover Theological Seminary (Mass.)
Letter dated Dec. 20, 1889, addressed to Churchill from Spooner (possibly Henry T. Spooner) regarding poetry of John Townsend Trowbridge.

Collection contains three articles prepared for the University Magazine of the University of North Carolina entitled "Counties in North Carolina that have Disappeared," "North Carolina in War," and "North Carolina Troops in South America," which concerns the Cartagena expedition to Venezuela, 1740. There is also a letter to Funk and Wagnalls Co. concerning a book they had published.
Champ Clark, nee James Beauchamp Clark, was U.S. Representative from Missouri (1893-1895, 1897-1921) and Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives (1911-1919).
A letter from Richard Sylvester (Major and Superintendent of the Washington, D.C., police department) to Rep. Clark, dated Jan. 1, 1911.
